## "Quo Vadis" and Christian Communities

Quo vadis as a Latin phrase is usually rendered "where are you going?" But the verb has the sense "rushing to." And the phrase emphasizes the end point, not the motion. This question has deep significance for Christian communities as The novel suggests: If I am not putting away everything else to move quickly towards Christ, I am going away from him.

The phrase comes from the legendary encounter between St. Peter and Christ as Peter was fleeing Rome during Nero's persecution. "Romam vado iterum crucifigi." I am going to Rome to be crucified again. At that very spot there is now a church (St. Mary in Palmis) familiarly known as Chiesa del Domine Quo Vadis.

## Religious Education and Evangelization Challenges

The Church seems to have lost its ability to speak to the modern world about God and Jesus teachings on account of some confusion. These words still stand and always will. Additionally, Instances of Pope John Paul II's support for the non- coercion theory are seen in the Assisi gatherings of October 1986 and January 2002.
